arm_group.description: Billberry powder 3 times daily for 2 months.

brief_summary.textblock:
In a double blinded, randomized, clinical trial of patients suffering from STEMI (ST-segment
      elevation myocardial infarction) or non-STEMI (non-ST-segment elevation myocardial
      infarction)compare the effect of 3 months of dietary supplement with bilberry extract on a
      range of parameters with prognostic importance in cardiovascular disease: lipids,
      inflammation, oxidative stress and heart function.

      Following inclusion of 8 individuals and as of February 12, 2014: Due to intolerance to
      "bilberry placebo powder" we have amended to the protocoll that the trial design is changed
      from blinded to open and that the bilberry arm of the trial carries on in an open design and
      that the control group will receive no dietary supplement.

clinical_study.brief_title: Bilberry as a Dietary Supplement After Myocardial Infarction (The BEAR SMART Trial)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with a diagnosis of STEMI as defined by chest pain suggestive for myocardial
             ischemia for at least 30 minutes before hospital admission, time from onset of
             symptoms of less than 24 hours, and an ECG with new ST-segment elevation in two or
             more contiguous leads of ≥0.2 mV in leads V2-V3 and/or ≥0.1 mV in other leads or a
             probable new-onset left bundle branch block.

          -  Patients with a diagnosis of non-STEMI as defined by a combination of; onset of
             symptoms such as central chest pain or an aggravated angina pectoris, with or without
             an ECG change with ST-segment lowering or an inverted T-wave, and at least two values
             with levels of troponin-T or troponin-I above the established margin of an MI.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Need for emergency coronary artery bypass grafting

          -  Inability to provide informed consent

          -  Age below 18 years

          -  Previous randomization in the BEAR SMART trial

          -  A daily intake, or the intent to start a daily intake of bilberries in some form
             (fresh berries, bilberry powder, bilberrysoup etc)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Need for emergency coronary artery bypass grafting

          -  Inability to provide informed consent

          -  Age below 18 years

          -  Previous randomization in the BEAR SMART trial

          -  A daily intake, or the intent to start a daily intake of bilberries in some form
             (fresh berries, bilberry powder, bilberrysoup etc)

facility.name: Department of Cardiology, Orebro University Hospital

clinical_study.official_title: Bilberry as a Dietary Supplement After Myocardial Infarction (The BEAR SMART Trial)

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Cardiology, Orebro University Hospital, Sweden

primary_outcome.description: The effect of intervention on a standardized physical challenge - the 6 minutes walk test

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The effect of intervention on the inflammatory marker CRPö

The effect of intervention on markers of inflammation: IL-6 (interleukin 6), TNF-α (tumor necrosis factor α), INF-γ (interferon γ), markers of oxidative stress: oxidized LDL, carbonylated proteins, 2-OHDG, H2O2, hexanoyl L lysine, nitrogen oxide synthase (NOS), markers of myocardial damage and heart failure: BNP (brain natriuretic peptide) and troponin I, markers of endothelial function: VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor), 8-isoprostane, E-selectin, measures of plasma lipids; total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, TGA (triacylglycerides), and measures of patient compliance and biological effect of bilberry supplementation: quercetin,
secondary_outcome.measure: Inflammatory markers and markers of heart function

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
